import numpy as np
import pandas as pd 
data = pd.read_csv("../input/kepler-exoplanet-search-results/cumulative.csv")
source.3c3f91a4: # useful Terminology and abbrevations KOI - kepler object of interest KIC - Kepler Input Catalogue transit - A transit occurs when a planet passes between a star and its observer. disposition tests - some tests performed to determine the nature of KOI as prescribed in this [paper](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013ApJS..204...24B/abstract) Orbital Period - The orbital period is the time a given astronomical object takes to complete one orbit around another object Barycentric Julian Date (BJD) - [BJD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barycentric_Julian_Date) is the Julian Date (JD) corrected for differences in the Earth's position with respect to the barycentre of the Solar System. stellar disc - A circumstellar disc (or circumstellar disk) is a torus, pancake or ring-shaped accumulation of matter composed of gas, dust, planetesimals, asteroids, or collision fragments in orbit around a star. planet disc - A protoplanetary disk is a rotating circumstellar disc of dense gas and dust surrounding a young newly formed star. insolution flux - Solar insolation is defined as the flux of solar radiation per unit of horizontal area for a given locality. (yep, its latin to me alright!) stellar effective temperature - The [effective temperature](https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007%2F978-3-642-11274-4_487#:~:text=The%20effective%20temperature%20is%20one%20of%20the%20two%20parameters%2C%20with,K%20for%20an%20M%20star.) of a star is the temperature of a  Black Body of the same size as the star and that would radiate the same total amount of electromagnetic power as emitted by the star. stellar surface gravity - The surface gravity may be thought of as the acceleration due to gravity experienced by a hypothetical test particle which is very close to the object's surface and mass of object is negligible Stellar Radius/solar radius - [solar radius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_radius) is a unit of distance used to express the size of stars in astronomy relative to the Sun. Right ascension -[Right ascension](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_ascension) (abbreviated RA; symbol α) is the angular distance of a particular point measured eastward along the celestial equator from the Sun at the March equinox to the (hour circle of the) point in question above the earth. declination - [declination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declination) (abbreviated dec; symbol δ) is one of the two angles that locate a point on the celestial sphere in the equatorial coordinate system, the other being hour angle. celestial sphere - the celestial sphere is an abstract sphere that has an arbitrarily large radius and is concentric to Earth. All objects in the sky can be conceived as being projected upon the inner surface of the celestial sphere
source.2135c99f:
# notes/description of columns  



kepid - ids given to "Kepler Objects of interest(KOI)" prior to kepler analysis (given by ground based team) ? (unique str)

kepoi_name - ids/names given to KOIs which have been analysed?  (unique str)

kepler_name - kepoi_name easy to read/remember version! (unique str)  

koi_disposition - 4 vals - results of disposition test run on each KOI by ***EXOPLANET ACHIVE*** (discreet categories)  
**(disposition test is an automated test, so it may be possible that human intervention may change the given designation)**

    - confirmed/non-dispositioned - corresponds to objects for which the disposition tests have not yet been completed.
    - candidate                   - corresponds to objects for which disposition tests have determined to be potential planet?
    - false positive              - corresponds to objects for which disposotion tests have determined that this KOI is not a ExoPlanet?
                  

koi_pdisposition - results of disposition test run on each KOI by ***KEPLER DATA***  (discreet categories)

koi_score - this column states the confidence in koi_pdisposition classification, for CANDIDATE, this implies confidence in KOI being CANDIDATE. for FP, this implies the confidence of KOI **not** being a FP ```([0,1])```

koi_fpflag_nt - A KOI whose light curve is not consistent with that of a transiting planet.```(0/1)```

koi_fpflag_ss - A KOI that is observed to have a significant secondary event, transit shape, or out-of-eclipse variability, which indicates that the transit-like event is most likely caused by an eclipsing binary. ```(0/1)```

koi_fpflag_co - The source of the signal is from a nearby star(centroid offset) ```(0/1)```

koi_fpflag_ec - The KOI shares the same period and epoch as another object and is judged to be the result of flux contamination in the aperture or electronic crosstalk. ```(0/1)```

koi_period - Orbital Period ```(days) ([0.241842544,129995.7784])```

koi_period_err1 & koi_period_err2 - pos & neg error in orbital period ```(.9f vals)```

koi_time0bk - weird way to represent time of discovery (The time corresponding to the center of the first detected transit in Barycentric Julian Day (BJD) minus a constant offset of 2,454,833.0 days. ```(BJC - 2454833.0)) ([120.5159138,1472.522306])```

koi_impact - The sky-projected distance between the center of the stellar disc and the center of the planet disc ```(measured in deg?)```

koi_impact_err1 & koi_impact_err2 - pos and neg error in impact dist

koi_duration - The duration of the observed transits. ```(hrs) ([0.052,138.54])```

koi_duration_err1 & koi_duration_err2 - pos and neg in error of duration of given KOI ```(.6f vals)```

koi_depth - transit depth is the ratio of the surface area of the star's disk blocked out by the planet's disk. So the transit depth is the square of the planet radius divided by the star's radius. ```(ppm) ([0.0,1541400.0])```

koi_depth_err1 & koi_depth_err2 - pos & neg error in transit depth. ```(.1f vals)```

koi_prad - The radius of the planet. Planetary radius is the product of the planet star radius ratio and the stellar radius. ```(times earth radii) ([0.08,200346.0])```

koi_prad_err1 & koi_prad_err2 - pos & neg error of planetary radius of given KOI

koi_teq - Approximation for the temperature of the planet ```(in kelvin) ([25.0,14667.0])```

koi_teq_err1 & koi_teq_err2 - pos & neg error of temperature of planet ```(they empty!, tagged to drop)```

koi_insol - Insolation Flux is another way to give the equilibrium temperature **see terminology**. ```(times earth flux) (0.2f vals)```

koi_insol_err1 & koi_insol_err2 - pos & neg errors of insolation_flux ```(0.2f vals)```

koi_model_snr - Transit Signal-to-Noise (cant find any references to this) ```([0,9054.7])```

koi_tce_plnt_num - planet number assigned to an object in that particular KOI ```([0,7])```

koi_tce_delivname - time of planet number assignment.

koi_steff - Stellar Effective Temperature ```(Kelvin) ([2661.0,15896.0])```

koi_steff_err1 & koi_steff_err2 - pos & neg errors in stellar effective temperature ```(0.1f vals)```

koi_slogg - Stellar Surface Gravity *see in terminology*  ```(log10(cm s-2)) ([0.047,5.364])```

koi_slogg_err1 & koi_slogg_err2 - pos & neg errors in stellar surface gravity of KOI

koi_srad - 	Stellar Radius ```(solar radii) ([0.109,229.908])```

koi_srad_err1 & koi_srad_err2 - pos & neg error of stellar radius of given KOI

koi_ra - KIC Right ascension ```(deg) ([279.85272,301.72076])```

koi_dec - KIC Declination ```(deg) ([36.577381,52.33601])```

koi_kepmag -  Kepler-band magnitude (mag)(idk what this is nor i can find any ref to this) ```TBD```
